info.desc: Mark up code from a programming, markup, or other machine-readable format.

page.title: Code Snippets

synopsis.code:
mal_inline_code = element code { mal_attr_link ?, attribute style { xsd:NMTOKENS } ?, attribute mime { text } ?, attribute * - (mal:* | local:*) { text } *,
mal_inline }

page.p: The code elements marks a portion of text from a computer language. This includes programming languages, markup languages, and the contents of any type of file with a structured syntax. Commands to run in an interactive shell, however, should use the cmd element, even though they may include snippets of shell programming.
The code element may be used to mark any portion of code, including comments or textual content that doesn't strictly follow any syntax.
The var element may be used inside a code element to indicate text that should be replaced by the user.

item.p: The style attribute takes a space-separated list of style hints. Processing tools should adjust their rendering according to those style hints they understand.
The mime attribute takes a valid MIME type. Processing tools may adjust their rendering for particular MIME types.
The code element can link to other pages or documents. See for more information.
The code element can have attributes from external namespaces. See for more information on external-namespace attributes on inline elements.

comment.p: Add processing expectations. For block, strip leading/trailing newline. Do not strip leading indentation.

section.title: Comparison to DocBook
section.p: The code element is similar to the code element in DocBook. Since Mallard does not attempt to model programming languages, the code may be used in place of numerous DocBook elements, including classname, constant, function, interfacename, methodname, parameter, structfield, structname, and varname. Additionally, since Mallard does not provide separate elements for marking portions of markup languages, the code element should be used in place of the DocBook elements markup and sgmltag.
